title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of protest, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To maintain the status quo

options.label: B
options.text: To challenge the status quo and bring about change

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a platform for self-expression

options.label: D
options.text: To gain economic benefits

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Arab Spring protests in the Middle East?

options.label: A
options.text: The establishment of democratic governments

options.label: B
options.text: The toppling of dictators, but a vacuum filled by militant and violent groups

options.label: C
options.text: The increase in economic growth

options.label: D
options.text: The decrease in poverty rates

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of expanding the frame of the possible in civic life?

options.label: A
options.text: It limits the scope of what can be achieved

options.label: B
options.text: It defines the boundaries of civic imagination and encourages creative thinking

options.label: C
options.text: It focuses on short-term gains

options.label: D
options.text: It ignores the opinions of others

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of powerful citizens in defining the terms of a contrast in civic life?

options.label: A
options.text: To remain neutral and avoid taking a stance

options.label: B
options.text: To set the terms of the contrast and think about a debate on their own terms

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on individual interests

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the opinions of others

multiple-choice.question: What was the goal of the activists pushing for a $15 minimum wage in the U.S.?

options.label: A
options.text: To achieve a short-term economic gain

options.label: B
options.text: To create a bigger debate about economic justice and prosperity

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the opinions of others

options.label: D
options.text: To maintain the status quo

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of seeking and achieving an early win in civic life?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a negative feedback loop and discourages further action

options.label: B
options.text: It sets in motion a positive feedback loop, creates momentum, and changes what people think is possible

options.label: C
options.text: It ignores the opinions of others

options.label: D
options.text: It focuses on short-term gains

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an early win that contributed to the eventual toppling of Poland's communist government?

options.label: A
options.text: The shipyard strikes in 1980

options.label: B
options.text: The nationwide effort that emerged over the next decade

options.label: C
options.text: The emergence of a new government

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in economic growth

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of policymakers, the media, and skeptical neighbors in achieving an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore their opinions and focus on individual interests

options.label: B
options.text: To pressure policymakers, use the media to change narrative, and make arguments in public

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on short-term gains

options.label: D
options.text: To maintain the status quo

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the long, slow slog in achieving lasting change in civic life?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a negative feedback loop and discourages further action

options.label: B
options.text: It sets in motion a positive feedback loop, creates momentum, and changes what people think is possible

options.label: C
options.text: It ignores the opinions of others

options.label: D
options.text: It focuses on short-term gains

multiple-choice.question: What is the spirit of protest and what can individuals do to be part of it?

options.label: A
options.text: The spirit of protest is about maintaining the status quo, and individuals can do nothing to be part of it

options.label: B
options.text: The spirit of protest is powerful, and individuals can be co-creators of what comes next by expanding the frame of the possible, choosing a defining fight, and securing an early win

options.label: C
options.text: The spirit of protest is about ignoring the opinions of others, and individuals can do nothing to be part of it

options.label: D
options.text: The spirit of protest is about focusing on short-term gains, and individuals can do nothing to be part of it

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self assembly, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A process of breaking down complex structures into simpler parts

options.label: B
options.text: A system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure on their own

options.label: C
options.text: A method of manufacturing objects using machines

options.label: D
options.text: A way of reproducing living organisms

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in biology?

options.label: A
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Protein folding

options.label: C
options.text: DNA replication

options.label: D
options.text: Cell division

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between amino acids and the 3-D structure of proteins?

options.label: A
options.text: Amino acids are randomly arranged, resulting in a 3-D structure

options.label: B
options.text: Amino acids interact with each other, resulting in a 3-D structure

options.label: C
options.text: Amino acids have no effect on the 3-D structure of proteins

options.label: D
options.text: Amino acids are only responsible for the color of proteins

multiple-choice.question: How can self assembly be used to build a perfect sphere?

options.label: A
options.text: By using traditional means of construction

options.label: B
options.text: By inflating the sphere like a bubble or a balloon

options.label: C
options.text: By creating many identical pieces that fit together precisely

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of magnets and a container

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential applications of self assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: Making objects that can only be seen by the human eye

options.label: B
options.text: Creating new forms of energy

options.label: C
options.text: Making molecular microchips for computers

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is one advantage of using self assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more expensive than traditional methods

options.label: B
options.text: It is less reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: C
options.text: It is only suitable for small-scale applications

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in the biological and chemical world

multiple-choice.question: How can self assembly be used to create 3-D structures with DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a machine to assemble the DNA molecules

options.label: B
options.text: By giving small molecular elements the right conditions to form themselves into organized pathways

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of magnets and a container

options.label: D
options.text: By creating many identical pieces that fit together precisely

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between self assembly and the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Self assembly has no effect on the environment

options.label: B
options.text: Self assembly can be used to create objects that are harmful to the environment

options.label: C
options.text: Self assembly can be used to create objects that are beneficial to the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Self assembly is only used in the biological and chemical world

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of using self assembly in construction?

options.label: A
options.text: Buildings can only be built in certain locations

options.label: B
options.text: Buildings can adapt to changing environmental conditions

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings can only be built using traditional materials

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings can only be built by humans

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of using self assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: To create objects that are more expensive than traditional methods

options.label: B
options.text: To create objects that are less reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: C
options.text: To create objects that can adapt to changing environmental conditions

options.label: D
options.text: To create objects that are only suitable for small-scale applications

multiple-choice.question: Who is the speaker talking about in the context of coming up with creative ideas and strategies?

options.label: A
options.text: A team of 10 people with diverse perspectives

options.label: B
options.text: A single person with a unique perspective

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker's colleagues with similar world views

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker's self

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result when a group of people with the same perspective come up with ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: A hundred useful ideas

options.label: B
options.text: Ten useful ideas

options.label: C
options.text: A thousand useful ideas

options.label: D
options.text: No useful ideas

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are surrounded by others who think in the same way, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their solution

options.label: B
options.text: They become less confident in their solution

options.label: C
options.text: They become more likely to find a solution

options.label: D
options.text: They become less likely to find a solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker warning against in terms of the attraction to people who think like us?

options.label: A
options.text: The pleasure of confirming our world view

options.label: B
options.text: The danger of not finding a solution

options.label: C
options.text: The problem of no uplift in collective intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: The danger of being wrong

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive diversity

options.label: B
options.text: Similar perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: The best model

options.label: D
options.text: The most complex solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with surrounding oneself with people who think in the same way as the complexity of the task increases?

options.label: A
options.text: You become more confident in your solution

options.label: B
options.text: You become less confident in your solution

options.label: C
options.text: You get no uplift at all in collective intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: You become more likely to find a solution

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the logic behind working with people who think like us?

options.label: A
options.text: It is extremely compelling

options.label: B
options.text: It is spectacularly wrong

options.label: C
options.text: It is a good idea

options.label: D
options.text: It is a bad idea

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker warning against in terms of the attraction to people who think like us, in terms of the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The pleasure centers lighting up

options.label: B
options.text: The brain not working

options.label: C
options.text: The brain not being sufficient to solve the problem

options.label: D
options.text: The brain being too complex

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker suggesting is the key to solving complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Surrounding oneself with people who think in the same way

options.label: B
options.text: Surrounding oneself with people who think in different ways

options.label: C
options.text: Having the best model

options.label: D
options.text: Having the most complex solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker saying will dominate the future of our economy, political institutions, and engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive diversity

options.label: B
options.text: Similar perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: The best model

options.label: D
options.text: The most complex solution
